introduction.p: During a 40-minute workout, a person riding an exercise machine burns calories at a rate of c calories per minute, where the function y = c(t) is given in the following figure. On the interval 0 \le t \le 10, the formula for c is c(t) = -0.05t^2 + t + 10, while on 30 \le t \le 40, its formula is c(t) = -0.05t^2 + 3t - 30.

statement.p: What is the exact total number of calories the person burns during the first 10 minutes of her workout?

hint.p: What are the units on the area of a rectangle found in a Riemann sum for the function y= c(t)?

answer.p: The person burned exactly \frac{400}{3} calories in the first 10 minutes of the workout.

solution.p: Since the units on a rectangle in a Riemann sum are cal/min for the height and min for the width, the units on the area of such a rectangle are calories, and hence the units on area under the curve y = c(t) are given in total calories. Hence, the total calories burned during the first 10 minutes of the workout is given by the definite integral \int_0^{10} c(t) \, dt. We use the FTC and evaluate the integral, finding that \int_0^{10} (-0.05t^2 + t + 10) \, dt =\mathstrut \amp \left. \left( -\frac{0.05}{3} t^3 + \frac{1}{2} t^2 + 10t \right) \right|_0^{10}=\mathstrut \amp \left( -\frac{0.05}{3} (10)^3 + \frac{1}{2} (10)^2 + 10(10) \right) - (-0 + 0 + 0)=\mathstrut \amp \frac{400}{3} \ \text{calories}. Thus, the person burned exactly \frac{400}{3} calories in the first 10 minutes of the workout.

statement.p: Let C(t) be an antiderivative of c(t). What is the meaning of C(40) - C(0) in the context of the person exercising? Include units on your answer.

answer.p: C(40) - C(0) = \int_0^{40} C'(t) \, dt = \int_0^{40} c(t) \, dt is the total calories burned on [0,40].

solution.p: We observe first that by the Total Change Theorem, C(40) - C(0) = \int_0^{40} C'(t) \, dt = \int_0^{40} c(t) \, dt, and therefore, as discussed in (a), the meaning of this value is the total calories burned on [0,40].

statement.p: Determine the exact average rate at which the person burned calories during the 40-minute workout.

solution.p:
The exact average rate at which the person burned calories on 0 \le t \le 40 is given by
c_{\text{AVG} [0,40]} = \frac{1}{40-0} \int_0^{40} c(t) \, dt . To calculate \int_0^{40} c(t) \, dt, we recognize that c(t) is defined in piecewise fashion, and use the additive property of the definite integral, which tells us that
\int_0^{40} c(t) \, dt = \int_0^{10} c(t) \, dt + \int_{10}^{30} c(t) \, dt + \int_{30}^{40} c(t) \, dt . We know from our work in (a) that \int_0^{10} c(t) \, dt = \frac{400}{3}. Since c(t) = 15 is constant on 10 \le t \le 20, it follows that \int_{10}^{30} c(t) \, dt = 15 \cdot 30 = 300. And finally, it is straightforward to show using c(t) = -0.05t^2 + 3t - 30 (or symmetry) on 30 \le t \le 40 that \int_{30}^{40} c(t) \, dt = \frac{400}{3}. Hence, \int_0^{40} c(t) \, dt =\mathstrut \amp \int_0^{10} c(t) \, dt + \int_{10}^{30} c(t) \, dt + \int_{30}^{40} c(t) \, dt=\mathstrut \amp \frac{400}{3} + 300 + \frac{400}{3}=\mathstrut \amp \frac{1700}{3} \approx 566.67 \ \text{calories}. Now, it follows that the exact average rate at which calories were burned on [0,40] is
c_{\text{AVG} [0,40]} = \frac{1}{40-0} \int_0^{40} c(t) \, dt = \frac{1}{40} \cdot \frac{1700}{3} = \frac{1700}{120} \approx 14.17 \ \text{cal/min} .

statement.p: At what time(s), if any, is the instantaneous rate at which the person is burning calories equal to the average rate at which she burns calories, on the time interval 0 \le t \le 40?

hint.p: Think carefully about which function tells you the instantaneous rate at which calories are burned.

answer.p: One time at which the instantaneous rate at which calories are burned equals the average rate on [0,40] is t = \frac{5}{3}(6 - \sqrt{6}) \approx 5.918.

solution.p:
It makes sense intuitively that there must be at least one time at which the instantaneous rate at which calories are burned equals the average rate at which calories are burned, as it would be impossible for a continuous instantaneous rate of change to always be above its average value. Since we know from (c) that c_{\text{AVG} [0,40]} = \frac{85}{6}, and c(t) tells us the instantaneous rate at which calories are burned, it follows that we want to solve the equation
c(t) = \frac{85}{6} . From the graph, it appears that there are two such values of t for which this equation is true, one in the first ten minutes, and one in the last ten. For instance, solving
-0.05t^2 + t + 10 = \frac{85}{6} , it follows that t = \frac{5}{3}(6 \pm \sqrt{6}) \approx 14.082, 5.918, only the second of which lies in 0 \le t \le 10. So one time at which the instantaneous rate at which calories are burned equals the average rate on [0,40] is t = \frac{5}{3}(6 - \sqrt{6}) \approx 5.918. Similar reasoning leads to the second time that lies in [30,40].
